label: U.S. NEWS
headline: This Earth Day, Biden Faces 'Headwinds' On Climate Agenda
dek: President Joe Biden plans to mark Earth Day in Seattle on Friday, but he's struggled to make progress on a sweeping environmental agenda.
author: Matthew Daly and Chris Megerian
contents: WASHINGTON (AP) — One year ago, Joe Biden marked his first Earth Day as president by convening world leaders for a virtual summit on global warming that even Russian President Vladimir Putin and China’s Xi Jinping attended. Biden used the moment to nearly double the United States’ goal for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, vaulting the country to the front lines in the fight against climate change.

child.name: Paul Deignan
child.text:
Little change over 30 years, way too short a time span for any reliable study on climate. That isn't even long enough for a good study on weather. Climatically speaking, 30 years is less than a nanosecond.

and by the way, all it takes is little global temperature change to make massive variations. We have little idea of what these changes will bring about. Reduction of glacial mass will cause isostatic rebound, what's that going to do along the "ring of fire"? While all that weight is being removed from landmasses, it is accumulating in the oceans, will this bring about more severe earthquakes and volcanic activity from weight transferred to different tectonic plates? Increased acidification of our oceans, desertification of our land areas, these are happening with the little variation we've already caused (yes, we've caused), we need to act.
When looking at things scientifically, there are papers that will seem to contradict majority findings but read beyond the summation and find timeframe and extent of data the findings are based on. Scientific conclusions are based on preponderance of evidence and scientific majority of people of the associated field. In this case, undeniable preponderance and overwhelming majority.

child.name: Martin Sandberg
child.text:
There is more than 30 years of fairly good data, of course. After warming from the little ice age starting at about 1850 the cooling from about 1940 - 1970, the last 30 years have been remarkably constant.

The point is that the models cannot support policies that will cost trillions of dollars. The data isn't there to support those policies either.

child.name: Paul Deignan
child.text:
Modeling is a prediction, a great model is considered ~70% reliable, a good tool, but not a stand alone conclusion. I don't trust any single model, but when different models predict basically the same kind of result (with degrees of variability), the conclusions over time become accepted.
If you noticed by my reply, there are more questions than answers for each % of a degree increase, adds risk factors and variables.

child.name: Martin Sandberg
child.text:
The models don't work. Again a long quote from Ed Zuiderwijk, PhD:

"There is something strange about climate models: they don’t converge. What I mean by that I will explain on the basis of historical determinations of what we now call the ‘Equilibrium Climate Sensitivity’ (ECS), also called the ‘Charney Sensitivity’ (ref 1), defined as the increase in temperature at the bottom of the Earth’s atmosphere when the CO2 content is doubled (after all feedbacks have worked themselves through). The early models by Plass (2), Manabe & co-workers (3) and Rowntree & Walker (4) in the 1950s, 60s and 70s gave ECS values from 2 degrees Centigrade to more than 4C. Over the past decades, these models have grown into a collection of more than 30 climate models brought together in the CMIP6 ensemble that forms the basis for the upcoming AR6 (‘6th Assessment Report’) of the IPCC. However the ECS values still cover the interval 1.8C to 5.6C, a factor of 3 difference in results. So after some 4 decades of development climate models have still not converged to a ‘standard climate model’ with an unambiguous ECS value; rather the opposite is the case." 

The whole article is well worth reading.

child.name: Paul Deignan
child.text: A standard climate model would require the same input variables, historic data sets that climate is based upon are not available across study areas (ice cores in some areas, lakebed samples in others (tree rings for better short term (last 1000 years) data)), so input variables cannot be standardized. Range of variability in studies is based in the scientist's preconceived theory, the input variables the scientist(s) feel are relevant and reliable, and where the data shows statistical significance. Mathematically/scientifically reliability of available data sets varies for long term historic data so convergence on a single (standardized) method is basically impossible.

child.name: Martin Sandberg
child.text:
Exactly! From further down in Ed Zuiderwijk's paper:

"If the astrophysicists were in the same situation as the climate model makers, they would still be working with, for example, a series of solar models that predict a value of X for the surface temperature give or take a few thousand degrees. Or that, in an engineering application, a new aircraft design should have a wing area of Y, but it could also be 3Y. You don’t have to be a genius to understand that such models are not credible."

That's why we cannot make policies that will cost trillions based on the models.

child.name: Paul Deignan
child.text:
Your reply saying that the models are not creditable hasn't shown up for me to directly reply to, so I'll do it here.
Just because models aren't standardized doesn't make them not creditable, they are based on statistical math.
Math doesn't lie.

There was always a slim to none chance that the monstrous BBB was going to be enacted into law. It was an FDR New Deal in its ambitions in a political climate that saw nothing like the mandate at the ballot box that Democrats and FDR received in 1932. The Democrats (especially “progressive” Democrats) need to decide just how big a priority doing what is practically possible to mitigate future global warming really is for them. That's versus other economic and social agendas.

What can be done needs to acknowledge a few realities. Global warming caused by carbon dioxide [as well as methane, . . .] is a global problem. It does not matter where the emission occurs. It doesn't matter how or why. It does not matter who. Just how much globally each year. Solutions must deal with the existing reality that over the 20th century and now into the 21st one primate species has in a relative comparison exhibited a bacterial rate of population growth relative to every other primate species. This while growing use to a life style that can only be supported with existing emission rates. How much reduction in quality of life are 330 million people in the US willing to accept (especially those who are not young, healthy, and living in urban areas) to even break even with the increase in emissions that the 1.38 billion [in India alone] want if they are going to achieve anything like the quality of life that will exist in the US?

comments.name: David Baxter
comments.text:
Anyone who opposes environmental efforts to fight climate change needs to explain it to their children and grandchildren.   The world that we have been destroying for the past 100 years is the only one we have, and our children and grandchildren are going to have to survive on it.     

It truly astounds me the way people glibly say, "oh, the world has been through this before, and survived, so we can survive this."   First of all, "We" won't survive this.    If you are over 40, it is highly likely that this will lead to the end for us.     It is our children and grandchildren who will have to solve the problem of how to survive it.

Secondly, why should we have to "Survive" this, when a few simple actions, which right now, are nothing more than a nuisance, would stop the problem from getting worse, and maybe even stop it from becoming life-threatening.

So, if you love your children, and your grand-children, as I do, then you need to get behind this push.    After all, it is only being driven by big corporations who are desperate to maintain their ridiculous profit margins.

If you really don't believe in climate change, or are not prepared to make the small changes require to alleviate it, or even perhaps solve it, then at least be honest with your children and tell them that "... you don't give a fuq about their future, and that your politics and 401K are much more important.

comments.text:
The American people cannot just look to the government to solve this problem.  Climate change means lifestyle changes.  People have a multitude of opportunities to effect change.  Electric cars are more common, solar and wind energy are more available, we can eat less meat, walk and bike more.    

We can also elect people that support taking action.  Putting this all on the President head is silly.  He is dealing with the political realities.  If people lead the government will follow, if people just expect the government to do it all they will get nothing.

comments.text: Oh I was waiting for it’s Joe Manchin’s fault..Biden made promises that he had little chance of getting climate done. And the far lefts push to shove it down Americas throat didn’t help. Joe Manhin sent a letter to Chuck Schumer in July of 2021 saying he would not support a bill that exceeded 1.5 Trillion dollars, Chuck Schumer hid that letter from Pelosi or anyone else who should have known of Manchin’s stance. Schumer thought he could shame Manchin into voting for the larger package, it didn’t work. So blame Joe Manchin all you want, you get nothing. There is still a chance to get something done. Actually the White House stopped talking about Manchin in an attempt to finally get a deal done. It’s time to stop whining about Manchin and work with him. Right now the left has become victims of Joe Manchin.

comments.text: For a president who is allegedly so concerned about global warming/climate change, why is he flying across the country to address global warming/climate change?  He is probably okay with his climate czar the haughty John Kerry flying around the world in a private jet, you know he's sooo important that his comfort is more important than his carbon footprint..

comments.name: dennis Ketty

comments.name: Frank Sterle
comments.text:
At least Biden seems to truly care. Many mainstream-news-media CEOs, and even senior editors, are unfazed by manmade global warming and its resultant extreme weather events.

I can readily recall the unsigned editorial that a local newspaper, The Surrey Now-Leader, printed just before Earth Day 2017, titled “Earth Day in need of a facelift”. Varied lengths of the same editorial, unfortunately, was also run by some sister newspapers, all owned by the same news-media mogul who also happens to be an aspiring oil refiner.
 
It opined that “some people would argue that [the day of environmental action] … is an anachronism,” that it should instead be a day of recognizing what we’ve societally accomplished. “And while it [has] served us well, in 2017, do we really need Earth Day anymore?” 
 
Until reading this, I had never heard anyone, let alone a mainstream news outlet, suggest we’re doing so well as to render Earth Day an unnecessary "anachronism”. Considering the sorry state of the planet’s natural environment, I still find it one of the most absurd and irresponsible acts of editorial journalism I've witnessed in my 35 years of news consumption.

child.name: Texas Pete
child.text: I keep hearing about "extreme weather" however the weather patterns I see today have been constant all my life.  What's different is how it's is reported.  Weather, even large events, used to be local or regional news. Now it's national news and it's reported as extraordinary events.

child.name: Mark Adkins
child.text: Record heat for several succeeding years now rules out the "constant weather patterns." But our own time left on earth is short, so who cares that we're leaving our grandkids a ruined planet, eh?

child.text: I'm not easily fooled.  I know a snow job when I see one.  So the earth is getting warmer there's no evidence it's our fault and there's especially no evidence man can reverse it.

child.name: Mark Adkins
child.text: So, you, a guy in Texas, simply poo-poo on the possibility that the planet's human population...all 7.9 billion of us...is causing climate change. What a shocker...not. Rest assured, plenty of smart people claim that there is indeed lots of evidence proving that climate-change is caused by humans. That said, I hope that you realize that with such a possibility...that humans are causing climate change...looming over us, we have the choice of either adequately addressing the problem, or going about our merry way, living our lives as usual. Even without climate change being factored in, the destruction that this society is inflicting to the landscape, fueled by a short-sighted mentality of "I want everything, including all of our natural resources, right now, to provide me with as much comfort and luxury as is possible!!!" will leave your and my grandkids with a highly diminished life, and a landscape overpopulated with humans of every sort. And conservative s still seem to care little about such a country that we're leaving our posterity. Very troubling, to say the least.
